physicalObject: Space Gray Apple MacBook Pro (closed)
proxyLocation: center of the desk, slightly toward the bottom of the image
utilizationMethod: Place the closed MacBook Pro on a tracked surface. Treat its screen hinge as the chest lid: users rest their palms on the aluminum top and lift the screen upward to simulate opening the chest. Optionally wrap the lid in a thin wood-grain decal to approximate the wooden texture. The laptop hinge provides resistance and a subtle click when fully opened.
ratingJustification: The MacBook’s hinge offers a realistic opening resistance and click, but its aluminum finish and smaller footprint diverge from the wooden texture and dimensions of the chest.

virtualObjectInfo.interactivity: its hinged lid could be opened
virtualObjectInfo.hapticFeedback: Users will lightly rest their palms and fingertips on a rigid, wooden-grained surface and interact primarily with a hinged lid. They should feel the subtle raised pattern of wood grain under their fingertips (medium grain height and spacing), the solid resistance of a wooden panel when pushing or pulling on the lid edge, and a distinct click or small bump as the hinge reaches its open/closed detent. A good physical proxy is a small wooden box (~0.6 m × 0.35 m × 0.5 m) with a functional metal hinge and a visible wood-grain finish so users can experience both the texture and the lid’s opening resistance.

virtualObjectInfo.hapticFeedback: Users will touch and manipulate a thin, smooth metal loop and shaft. They should feel a cool, polished finish under their fingertips, the rounded, uniform thickness of the ring (about 5–6 cm diameter), and the solid, unyielding hardness of metal throughout. The key’s ring-shaped head provides a precise tactile outline: a seamless circular profile with a small gap for fingertip insertion. An ideal proxy is an actual house key or a metal key-fob ring: roughly 0.06 m thick at the loop, rigid and smooth, so users get the correct sense of outline and surface finish.

virtualObjectInfo.hapticFeedback: Users will grip a solid, gun-shaped frame, rest their trigger finger on a pullable trigger, and experience a two-stage tactile response when firing. The grip should feel firm and comfortable, the barrel and slide surfaces hard and temperature-neutral. When the user presses the trigger, they should feel initial spring tension, then a sharper ‘break’ as the trigger clicks over, followed by a short, sharp vibration simulating recoil. A suitable proxy is a toy or dummy pistol with a working trigger mechanism and a bit of mass in the barrel to transmit feedback, so users can feel both trigger resistance and a brief kickback.

virtualObjectInfo.description: a steering wheel in a car
virtualObjectInfo.hapticFeedback: Users will grasp a circular rim roughly 0.4 m across and rotate it continuously. They should feel the continuous curved outline under both palms and fingertips, a firm but slightly textured rubber or plastic grip surface, and a consistent rotational resistance with subtle detents or friction to convey mechanical linkage. A steering-wheel replica (or a bicycle handlebar ring) with a diameter of about 40 cm and a lightly textured grip surface is an excellent proxy to reproduce both the outline and the interactive rotation feedback.

They should feel the continuous curved outline under both palms and fingertips, a firm but slightly textured rubber or plastic grip surface, and a consistent rotational resistance with subtle detents or friction to convey mechanical linkage. A steering-wheel replica (or a bicycle handlebar ring) with a diameter of about 40 cm and a lightly textured grip surface is an excellent proxy to reproduce both the outline and the interactive rotation feedback.

physicalObject: Space Gray Apple MacBook Pro (closed)
proxyLocation: center of the desk, slightly toward the bottom of the image
utilizationMethod: User reaches out and presses down on the closed laptop lid between thumb and fingers as if squeezing a tomato, feeling the rigid metal top.
ratingJustification: The MacBook’s metal shell is extremely hard with virtually no compliance or sink-in, completely failing to emulate the soft, deformable feel of a tomato.

virtualObjectInfo.hapticFeedback: Users will press or squeeze a soft, compliant object. They should feel low initial resistance that yields under fingertip pressure, a slight sink-in as the surface deforms, and gentle ‘give’ without a hard stop. On full compression, a subtle change in resistance reminds them of the flesh inside. A soft foam ball or a stress-ball shaped and sized like a tomato (∼0.17 m diameter) provides the correct softness and deformability for users to experience the smashable feel.

physicalObject: Space Gray Apple MacBook Pro (closed)
proxyLocation: center of the desk, slightly toward the bottom of the image
utilizationMethod: Hold the closed MacBook Pro by its front edge like a handle and swing the hinge-side as a pseudo-head
ratingJustification: Flat, wide profile with no cylindrical grip or off-center mass – feels nothing like a hammer

virtualObjectInfo.inertia: relatively heavy with the center of mass concentrated at one end
virtualObjectInfo.hapticFeedback: Users will grip a cylindrical, round handle and swing a weighty head. They should feel the handle’s uniform round cross-section under their palm and fingers (about 2–3 cm diameter), and the pronounced heft at one end as they lift or swing—this off-center mass creates a natural torque and swing-through resistance. A solid metal or weighted toy hammer with a heavy head and smooth wooden or plastic handle (~0.25 m × 0.42 m overall) makes a good proxy by delivering the correct inertia distribution and outline of the handle.
